alert.note: Alert for Mercer (West Virginia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 30 at 12:29AM EDT by NWS Blacksburg
info.description: .Minor to moderate flooding continues within the warned area as a result of excessive rainfall during the past 24 to 36 hours. Several creeks and streams, especially in Mercer county remain in flood and will through the night. Some roads remain closed. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 245 AM EDT EARLY THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall will continue overnight. * WHERE...Portions of southwest Virginia and southeast West Virginia, including the following counties, in southwest Virginia, Bland and Tazewell. In southeast West Virginia, Mercer. * WHEN...Until 245 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Several roads, especially in the Bluefield area, remain closed due to flooding. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1221 AM EDT, Gauge reports indicated heavy rain due to excessive runoff from heavy rainfall. Flooding is already ongoing or imminent n the warned area. The Bluestone river at Spanishburg continues to rise and is now in major flood at 15.7 feet. Flood stage is 12 ft. and major flood stage is 17 ft. The river is expected to continue to rise for the next several hours and may approach 20 ft. later tonight. At 15 ft., the Spanishburg Elementary School and Rich Creek Baptist church become flooded. At 14 ft., numerous portions of U.S. Highway 19 are impacted by flood waters south of Spanishburg. Now that the river has risen to over 17 ft., additional significant flooding is possible throughout areas adjacent to the river. All precautions should be taken immediately to protect lives and property! - This includes the following streams and drainages... Brush Creek, Beaver Branch, Big Spring Branch, Bratton Branch, Bluestone River and Blacklick Creek. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Bluefield, Princeton, Rocky Gap, Camp Creek, Spanishburg, Pocahontas and Bramwell. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of flooding, including mudslides or flooded roads, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and on Twitter.
